text: In mathematics, the power set of a set S, written as P(S) or \mathcal{P}(S), is the set of all subsets of S. In terms of cardinality, a power set is larger than the set it originates from. If S is a finite set with n elements, then P(S) would have 2^n elements. ==Examples== * The power set of \\{2, 5\\} is \\{\\{\\}, \\{2\\}, \\{5\\}, \\{2, 5\\}\\}. * The power set of \\{3, 4, 10\\} is \\{\\{\\}, \\{3\\}, \\{4\\}, \\{10\\}, \\{3, 4\\}, \\{3, 10\\}, \\{4, 10\\}, \\{3, 4, 10\\}\\}. == Related pages == * Zermeloâ€“Fraenkel set theory, which includes an axiom on power set == References == Category:Set theory Category:Algebra
title: Power set
